post.title: A report on the camping trip
post.author: Jackson Hayes
post.content:
Ya, it's been like a week since I have posted on here, I would say I have been to busy, but I would more say that I have been to lazy to write anything.

That being said it was a busy, weird fun weekend and week. Ok so, the quick version of the camping trip I went on: On Saturday morning my host mom asked me if I wanted to go, and I was only half positive that she was asking me if I wanted to go and not just telling me that they were going. So, Sunday morning I got prepared and was hanging around the house waiting for instructions. Eventually we left, but I waited around nervously for quite a while.

We piled in the car with my host Mom's "friends." These guys were both about my age so I didn't quite understand how they would have been acquainted. I never asked.

After a 3 hour trip, we stopped at a rest area. This is when I first saw the magnitude of the group we were traveling with. It was about five cars full of people. Not a small camping group.

After the stop we then had about an hour trip up the mountain on what I can only describe as treacherous and uncomfortable roads. The funniest, but also most nerve-racking, thing was when we were about half way up there was a back hoe blocking the road. On closer inspection, what it was doing was clearing a rock slide. EEEEKK.

After that bit of scary, we made it to the campsite. It was quite beautiful. Please refer to pictures I am not going to describe it.

The trip was mildly fun, not really. The problem was that I was on a mountain with a bunch of people whose language I barely speak, who I also don't know—and then—they were speaking a dialect that I don't understand a word of. So I wouldn't say that I was able to engage in too much conversation, which was the reason I thought going on the trip would really be worth while. So basically I just walked around the camp site aimlessly, taking some photos.

In the evening the force feed me an unhealthy amount of food. Way. Too. Much. Food. I'm full apparently wasn't a good enough, although true, excuse.

I also discovered on the trip that my illness, that I thought was a sinus infection or an ear infection was actually just a cold. So that was good, but it made me a bit uncomfortable. I think the vast majority of any time someone said something to me on the trip was: are you sick or would you like to eat some of this.

And that's all I've got to say about that.
